metadata.title: A Multi‐Purpose Heliophysics L4 Mission
metadata.abstract: The Earth‐Sun Lagrangian point 4 is a meta‐stable location at 1 AU from the Sun, 60° ahead of Earth's orbit. It has an uninterrupted view of the solar photosphere centered on W60, the Earth's nominal magnetic field connection to the Sun. Such a mission on its own would serve as a solar remote sensing observatory that would oversee the entire solar radiation hemisphere with significant relevance for protecting Moon and Mars explorers from radiation exposure. In combination with appropriately planned observatories at L1 and L5, the three spacecraft would provide 300° longitude coverage of photospheric magnetic field structure, and allow continuous viewing of both solar poles, with >3.6° elevation. Ideally, the L4 and L5 missions would orbit the Sun with a 7.2° inclination out of the heliographic equator, 14.5° out of the ecliptic plane. We discuss the impact of extending solar magnetic field observations in both longitude and latitude to improve global solar wind modeling and, with the development of local helioseismology, the potential for long‐term solar activity forecasting. Such a mission would provide a unique opportunity for interplanetary and interstellar dust science. It would significantly add to reliability of operational observations on fast coronal mass ejections directed at Earth and for human Mars explorers on their round‐trip journey. The L4 mission concept is technically feasible, and is scientifically compelling.

. Introduction A Multi-Purpose Heliophysics L4 Mission
10.1029/2021SW002777This is an open access article under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non-commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.
Space weather (SWx) forecasting is a complex problem, spanning vastly different regions of space and involving several scientific disciplines within and beyond Heliophysics. The main pillar that all SWx forecasts rely on is rapid availability of sets of observations of the Sun and inner heliosphere measured on the ground and on space platforms. Budgetary realism dictates the locations of observatories and their instrumentation to be chosen carefully so they address short-term needs and lead to long-term improvements.It is important to note that much of the underlying physics of SWx is not yet understood. This includes, to name just a subset of phenomena, the initiation of flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs), the Abstract The Earth-Sun Lagrangian point 4 is a meta-stable location at 1 AU from the Sun, 60° ahead of Earth's orbit. It has an uninterrupted view of the solar photosphere centered on W60, the Earth's nominal magnetic field connection to the Sun. Such a mission on its own would serve as a solar remote sensing observatory that would oversee the entire solar radiation hemisphere with significant relevance for protecting Moon and Mars explorers from radiation exposure. In combination with appropriately planned observatories at L1 and L5, the three spacecraft would provide 300° longitude coverage of photospheric magnetic field structure, and allow continuous viewing of both solar poles, with >3.6° elevation. Ideally, the L4 and L5 missions would orbit the Sun with a 7.2° inclination out of the heliographic equator, 14.5° out of the ecliptic plane. We discuss the impact of extending solar magnetic field observations in both longitude and latitude to improve global solar wind modeling and, with the development of local helioseismology, the potential for long-term solar activity forecasting. Such a mission would provide a unique opportunity for interplanetary and interstellar dust science. It would significantly add to reliability of operational observations on fast coronal mass ejections directed at Earth and for human Mars explorers on their round-trip journey. The L4 mission concept is technically feasible, and is scientifically compelling.Plain Language SummaryThis work describes the advantages of placing a spacecraft at a point 60° ahead of Earth in its orbit, which offers advantages for viewing areas on the surface of the Sun that hold critical clues about solar ionizing radiation that may affect astronauts on/at the moon or on the way to and from Mars. We describe that a combination of missions ahead and behind the Earth in its orbit would provide additional benefits, even more so if injected in an orbital plane that is tilted by ∼14°. Solar remote sensing observations from these platforms would significantly improve models of the magnetic field and solar wind of the Sun and in the inner solar system, by covering more solar surface area in longitude, but also of the polar regions. This would help us better understand when solar eruptions affect the Earth's magnetosphere. Other benefits, including long-term advance forecasting of solar activity and the understanding of dust populations in the near-Sun environment are also discussed. An analysis of launch capabilities shows that such a mission concept, even launching both suggested missions together, is feasible.POSNER ET AL.

acceleration of the solar wind and that of particles to high energies. At the time of writing, the Parker Solar Probe (PSP) and Solar Orbiter missions are exploring the immediate vicinity of the solar corona and the inner heliosphere. They will likely provide observations that advance understanding of some of the above listed unsolved physics problems.

What is already understood is that the most severe SWx in the inner heliosphere, including the Earth-Moon system and Mars, originates at the Sun. The difficulty in forecasting solar eruptions is expressed well in the quote from Schrijver (2009): "Flux rope-emergence may lead to major flares within about a quarter of a day" …"the vast majority of major flares are associated with flux emergence (within the preceding day or so) in the form of tightly wound flux ropes in active regions with large-scale twist…"; "Conversely, no major flares occur in regions that have a largely potential appearance, or more than about a day after the emergence of substantial flux ropes…"

The severity of the impact depends on the relative locations of the source of SWx on the Sun, often an active region or filamentary magnetic neutral line, with respect to the observer, and the type of SWx in question. This work focuses on two aspects of severe SWx: arrival time forecasts of CMEs, the main source of geomagnetic storms, and other geoeffective solar wind structures, and SEP events in which particles are accelerated to high energies near the Sun. Geomagnetically active structures propagate near-radially from the Sun to 1 AU, therefore it is important to view the Sun's central meridian region and to have knowledge of the structure of the solar wind between the Sun and Earth. The propagation of energetic particles is generally guided by magnetic fields in the heliosphere, which, on average, connect Earth with regions near the W limb of the Sun.


Space Weather Observations From Lagrangian Points

The Earth-Sun Lagrangian points 4 and 5 (L4, L5) form equilateral triangles with the Earth-Moon system (hereafter "Earth") and the Sun. L4 is located in Earth orbit 60° ahead of the Earth, whereas L5 lags 60° behind the Earth. As compared to the remainder of Lagrangian points in a three-body system, L4 and L5 are stable, and natural objects are known to populate them, which is particularly true for the Sun-Jupiter system. In 1978, the International Sun-Earth Explorer 3 (ISEE-3) spacecraft was the first one to be placed as an "interplanetary monitoring system" in a halo orbit near any Lagrangian point (Earth-Sun L1) (Tsurutani & Baker, 1979).

While ISEE-3's mission was to provide context observations for its sister spacecraft ISEE1 and 2 in the magnetosphere, the value of Lagrange point observations for SWx forecasting and nowcasting was soon realized, including its unobstructed view of the Sun, and its placement that exposes it to solar wind flow unobstructed by magnetospheric interference. Since then, several missions have been placed in Earth-Sun L1. In terms of L4 and L5, there have not been attempts of placing spacecraft, despite the advantages of viewpoints that would allow the observation of the Sun-Earth line from the "side." The two-spacecraft STE-REO mission -drifted through the Earth-Sun L4 (STEREO A) and L5 (STEREO-B) in the 2009/2010 time frame and attempted for the first time to image the heliosphere between Sun and Earth with a wide field of view. However, the Sun passed the deepest solar minimum conditions in nearly 100 years at the time of this passage. While there were many CMEs, they have not resulted in significant geomagnetic activity nor were any accompanied by significant SEP events. Studies about observations from beyond L4 and L5 (e.g., Hess & Zhang, 2014) during the rising phase of solar activity were able to demonstrate that CME disturbances could be traced successfully from the Sun all the way to Earth.

Other uses of L4 or L5 were proposed. These include the early detection of active regions (ARs) from behind the East limb of the Sun from L5, and the early detection of co-rotating (quasi-stationary) interaction regions Gopalswamy, Davila, StCyr, et al., 2011). Pevtsov et al. (2020) compared placement options for solar magnetographs at L5 and L4 and came to the conclusion that the L5 position would be more advantageous of increasing the accuracy of models that attempt to simulate the inner-heliosphere solar wind structure based on two-point magnetographic remote sensing of the Sun, in particular because the eastern limb region is the "oldest" directly observed data that would flow into these global models. Any addition of undetected active region flux would lead to effects unaccounted for in these models unless a spacecraft records the solar magnetic field from a position at or near L5.

Not a significant part of the discussions in the published literature regarding L4 and L5 missions are precursors of SEP events, a main source of ionizing radiation in the inner heliosphere that can, under extreme conditions, lead to temporary or permanent loss of hardware in space, but also to severe radiation effects on humans exploring the Moon or Mars. Another aspect that has not been discussed elsewhere is the inclination of spacecraft "parked" in L4 and L5, and whether inclinations out of the ecliptic plane can improve critical SWx forecasting products.


Manuscript Organization

The manuscript is organized as follows: Section 2 discusses solar radiation hazards for human exploration, introduces the solar radiation hemisphere (SRH) and the concept of the magnetic horizon, and discusses the potential of an L4 mission to contribute to advance knowledge of radiation hazards; Section 3 discusses the value of missions in the three Lagrangian points L1, L4, and L5 for modeling of the inner heliosphere solar wind and forecasting of the arrival of geomagnetic disturbances at Earth; Section 4 explores the opportunities for studying interplanetary and interstellar dust (ISD) with the suggested mission concept. Section 5 discusses a plausible L4/L5 mission architecture, including the results of an initial L4 mission design study, and specific suggestions for the combined L4/L5 mission architecture. Section 6 discusses and summarizes our analyses.


An L4 Mission That is Critical for Human Exploration

Extreme SEP events were discovered in ionization effects they create at ground level (Lange & Forbush, 1942), therefore later referred to as Ground Level Enhancements (GLEs). Ions in GLEs reach energies of ∼1 GeV or more. With multi-spacecraft missions it has been found that extreme SEPs can be detected all around the Sun, filling the entire inner heliosphere with elevated fluxes of ions and electrons. Their most rapid onset, highest overall intensity and shortest time from onset to peak intensity in the heliosphere is usually observed along the direct magnetic connection to the source region. At 1 AU in-ecliptic distance from the Sun, SEPs with the potential to be most severe in intensity and with the most rapid rise in intensity are linked to flares/CMEs that originate near ∼W60. Or, in other words, if one had the option to place the source of a specific SEP at a specific solar longitude, the intensity of this SEP would be largest at Earth if it were placed at or near W60 (see, e.g., Richardson et al., 2014, Figure 23).

Several factors influence the actual magnetic connection distance of an observer from the best magnetic connection to the solar source region. Highly non-radial fields near ARs can play a major role, as shown recently by the PSP mission, which in April 2019 observed a set of two small SEP events while nominally connected about 80°E of the source region (Leske et al., 2020), concluding that "the field lines expanded over a wide longitudinal range between the active region in the photosphere and the corona." The source of these small SEPs were jets emanating from AR 12738, which erupted in a westward (i.e., PSP-ward) direction. Moreover, overarching magnetic field lines of the active region suggest a broad, overlaying non-radial extension of this AR westward. It remains an open question as to whether small, jet-associated SEP events are more susceptible to non-radial coronal magnetic forces than larger SEP events that often occur alongside fast CMEs, which disrupt the large-scale magnetic structures in the quiet corona.

Another influence on solar source longitude stems from solar wind speed. Note. Source longitudes are given with respect to the planet's location. Magnetic field lines anchored at the solar limb (90°W) are at the edge of remote-sensing visibility from the respective planet, the magnetic horizon. The right column lists approximate solar wind speed likelihoods measured at Earth, based on the OMNI data set (Li et al., 2016). also shown.) The likelihood of solar wind speed intervals, derived from long-term observations at 1 AU that is combined in the OMNI data set, is shown in the right column (Li et al., 2016).

The solar region of ∼W60 as viewed from Earth coincides with the central meridian of an L4 mission but is hidden from view from the L5 vantage point. Please note that SEP events are considered well-connected to Earth if their source longitude does not differ dramatically from W60, certainly within 60° in longitude of the W60 location. This also means that from the Earth/Moon point of view SEPs originating from the region behind the solar west limb (highlighted in bold in Table 1) are still well connected and can reach high intensities rather rapidly. Even taking into account non-radial magnetic forces in the solar corona, remote-sensing from a combination of L1 and L4 would be able to observe all well-connected sources for solar energetic particles that pose a radiation hazard for the Earth-Moon system.

The sudden exposure to energetic protons from SEP events beyond the Earth's magnetosphere and en-route to the Moon or Mars can, in extreme cases, lead to acute radiation sickness, an impairing, mission-endangering condition for astronauts. Timely warnings of their impending occurrence may significantly reduce radiation exposure by allowing astronauts enough time to move to a radiation shelter. Longer-term warnings would even allow for better mission planning, ideally avoiding the most severe SEP events.

Several techniques currently exist to provide short-term forecasts of hazards from SEP events, tailored to a variation of proton energy ranges or integral fluxes. "Protons" (Balch, 2008) relies upon a combination of inputs, the time-integrated and peak soft X-ray flux, along with simultaneous Types II and IV radio bursts, for determining the probability of occurrence of a proton event. "UMASEP" (Núñez, 2011) exploits the rise of relativistic protons at Earth, in combination with a near-simultaneous flare X-ray event from the Sun. The "PPS" model (Smart & Shea, 1979) is in use by the Air Force Research Laboratory (AFRL). Needed inputs of the AFRL PPS model are solar flare locations, peak or time-integrated X-ray or radio fluxes of the flare and their times of onsets and maxima. The ESPERTA concept (Laurenza et al., 2009(Laurenza et al., , 2018 is not currently in use due to the lack of near-real-time data is the that uses time-integrated low-frequency (<1 MHz) type III radio burst intensity along with flare X-ray size and location parameters. Richardson et al. (2014) have found that about 30% of the most hazardous SEP events in the two-STEREO era originate from behind the western solar limb of a 1 AU observer (including Earth). The lack of behind-the-west-limb flare observations affects the accuracy of many of the leading current SEP forecasting systems, including protons, UMASEP, PPS and ESPERTA. Even though methods exist that do not require direct flare observations for forecasting the occurrence of a SEP event (REleASE, see Section 2.3), such methods combined with those methods that do require flare inputs would likely result in improved accuracy and reliability. The lack of flare observations beyond the western limb of the Sun is therefore identified as a significant hindrance.


The Solar Radiation Hemisphere and Magnetic Horizon

Longer-term SEP forecasts would first and foremost depend on understanding and predicting solar activity more generally. Recently, progress has been made in flare forecasting (e.g., , Kusano et al., 2020, and it is expected that with machine learning patterns leading up to eruptions (flares and CMEs) can be recognized even more reliably.

All these methods have in common, when applied to solar radiation forecasting, that the area of the Sun where most significant SEP events affecting the Earth environment originate, needs continuous observations. We introduce the definition of the SRH as the solar hemisphere stretching from 30°E to 150°W with respect to Earth. We would like to stress, in order to avoid any misunderstanding, that this hemisphere is not more likely to generate solar activity and/or SEPs than its counterpart, but it represents the area of the Sun that is best magnetically connected with Earth, so that any solar particle event originating from there has a high likelihood to be observable at and affecting the near-Earth environment. Moreover, as Figure 1 shows, the most vulnerable phase of the transfer of human explorers to Mars and back from Mars is exposed to the SRH. This aspect will be discussed in more detail in the next section.

The concept of the SRH is not merely theoretical. As mentioned above, Richardson et al. (2014) have identified the proportion of SEP events measured at 1 AU by STEREO A, B, and Earth (SoHO), originated from behind the western solar limb. Moreover, the origin of most three-spacecraft events analyzed by them originated in the SRH, here reproduced as a histogram surrounding the Sun in Figure 1.

An observatory stationed at L4, ahead of the Earth in its orbit, could provide remote sensing of the entire SRH, as shown in Figure 1. Thus, the necessary flare observations, so far unavailable to forecasters responsible for radiation protection of astronauts, would become available for post-eruption models such as protons, PPS, UMASEP and ESPERTA and add a significant level of safety for exploration plans.

All-clear forecasts refer to probabilistic, pre-eruption predictions of the occurrences of solar eruptive phenomena, such as flares, radio bursts or CMEs, which often are linked also with SEPs.   The Solar Radiation Hemisphere is the relative solar hemisphere from a 1 AU observer (such as the Earth-Moon system in this case) that has the potential to severely affect its local radiation environment. It spans solar longitudes from 30°E to 150°W relative to the observer and is centered around and fully observable from a location 60° ahead in the observers' orbit (here the Sun-Earth L4 location). The histogram shows the relative source longitudes of maximum solar energetic particle (SEP) 14-24 MeV proton intensity of all three-spacecraft SEP events in the STEREO era as described in Richardson et al. (2014). The relative trajectories of the Earth/Moon system with respect to sample Hohmann transfer orbits to and from Mars, and the Earth/Sun Lagrangian Point 4. The narrow, dashed lines indicate the relative orbital distances of Earth and Mars from the Sun. The thicker dashed line indicates an idealized interplanetary magnetic field line for a solar wind speed near average in the ecliptic plane. It connects to a location near 60°W on the Sun. Simulated 2-D SEP electron intensity contours (Strauss et al., 2017) for an event that is well connected with Earth are shown as well.

an all-clear forecast can be extended to with sufficient reliability, even scheduling entire round-trip missions to the Moon may become possible. Yet the issuance of such an all-clear would depend critically on the observations of the SRH.

The concept of the SRH is also closely related to the concept of the Magnetic Horizon (MH). The (wider) MH is defined as the surface that the full set of magnetic field lines originating from the solar limb form. It separates the regions, in which magnetic field lines directly connected to flaring can or cannot be fully detected from the viewpoint of the observer. A second definition of the MH applies to the maximum angle at which three-dimensional vector magnetic fields on the Sun may still be resolved, or EUV features assigned their respective solar source longitude/latitude. Such a (narrower) MH is located approximately 20° from the solar limb. This aspect is discussed in the context of solar polarimetry in Section 3.2.

The wider MH extends into a three-dimensional shape that ideally intersects the ecliptic plane along the Parker magnetic field lines emanating from the solar E and W limbs. The location of the MH in the heliosphere is dependent on the speed of the solar wind. As inferred from Table 1, in which a magnetic connection of 300 km/s solar wind speed to 81.8°W is established, the MH intersects 1 AU only about 8.2°W of the observer's location. At higher solar wind speeds, such as 500 km/s, the MH's intersection with 1 AU is located about 40°W.


L4 and Lunar Exploration

We utilize 2-D particle transport simulations in order to illustrate the hazard posed by eruptions from just beyond the MH, far enough behind the W limb so that the associated flare would not be visible from the Earth-Sun line. The simulation is observation driven with respect to heliospheric turbulence quantities and relies on first principles for deriving transport coefficients (Strauss, et al., 2017). The model is successful in reproducing anisotropies, longitudinal distributions, and times of onset, initially for electrons at or below 100 keV. More recently, the model has been used to simulate higher-energy (∼1 MeV) electrons and ∼40 MeV protons as well (Posner & Strauss, 2020). The calculated mean-free-paths for 40 MeV protons are shown in the insert of Figure 2 as a function of radial distance. For the parallel mean-free-path, at Earth's position, we obtain a value of ∼0.3AU, while the ratio of the perpendicular to the parallel mean-free-path is ∼4%. Note, however, that these parameters have a significant and non-trivial radial dependence. We use the same set-up as Posner and Strauss (2020) with the exception that the source region is narrower, spanning 5° in longitude.

Figures 2-4 show the outcomes of simulation runs, with the source of the eruption in each case located at 105°W, that is, the flare would not be visible from Earth. From L4, this source would be located at 45°W of the central meridian, well within view and, importantly, given appropriate instrumentation would be measurable without being adversely affected by limb foreshortening. For Figure 2, solar wind speed of 500 km/s is used. Figure 3 assumes slow, 300 km/s solar wind for the simulation, for comparison. Figure 4 provides the absolute flux differences between the two runs. The heliospheric magnetic field under slow solar wind conditions connects the Earth-Moon system with a region near the MH (or solar W limb), 82°W for 300 km/s. As the difference in simulations shows, slow solar wind shifts the particle flux significantly eastward, toward the Earth-Moon system. The threat of rapid flux enhancements posed by SEPs from just behind the MH is quite significant. Figure 5 shows the intensities of the Earth-Moon system as compared to the maximum flux at 1 AU, for both 300 km/s solar wind and 500 km/s solar wind. The flux at the Earth-Moon system is only marginally lower, by a factor of ∼3.75, than that of the direct magnetic connection to the source region further west.  Kim et al. (2005) show that the dose rate from high-energy protons in extreme SEPs behind moderate amounts of shielding can rise rapidly and can reach up to 20 cGy/ hr, while the lower threshold of short-term radiation exposure that can cause acute radiation syndrome is around 1 cGy/hr. Assuming the magnetic-connection-distance reduction in proton flux of a factor of 3.75 alone from a hypothetical worst-case SEP event originating behind the W limb as shown in Figure 5 would not sufficiently reduce biological effects. As discussed in Posner and Strauss (2020) in more detail, timely warnings of extreme SEPs can lead to significant reductions in radiation exposure. This set of figures is chosen to stress how important it is for Lunar exploration alone to view the region behind the solar W limb, ideally from L4. Alternatively, the occurrence of slow solar wind should be considered as high risk for Lunar exploration. The likelihood of occurrence of such slow solar wind is not negligible, ∼8% according to Li et al. (2016) (see Table 1).

Moreover, SEP forecasting capabilities that require information from imaging instruments may have difficulties with eruptions that arise at the W limb, or even just on the near side of the Sun, but outside the "narrow" MH as defined earlier. Such eruptions can reach even higher relative proton intensities in the Earth-Moon system than our example of 105°W has shown. An L4 mission would support forecasting in such instances as the source location would be well inside the narrow MH from that vantage point.


L4 and Mars Exploration

A circumstance of note in the discussion of radiation safety for human exploration of Mars is the recurring relative positions of human Mars explorers at any phase of their journey with respect to Earth and its associated Lagrangian points. Human explorers will typically follow the Hohmann (1925) minimum-energy trajectory to and from Mars, which allows the transport of the maximum payload and shielding mass for a given energy expenditure. Please note that we discuss the rationale for and the consequences of faster trajectories in Section 2.4. Due to its non-negligible orbital eccentricity, the departure/arrival distances of Mars from the Sun have moderate influence on those positions but don't change the overall picture. Figure  Intensity contours of ∼40 MeV protons, 2 h after the injection at the Sun as simulated with a 2-D particle transport code. The source of the injection is 5° wide and located 15° behind the solar W limb. A magnetic field line from the location of the eruption out to 1 AU is included. Views of the Sun from L1 (dashed) and L4 (solid) are highlighted. The assumed solar wind speed is 500 km/s in this simulation. The insert in the lower left shows the transport coefficients, used in this work to simulate the transport of 40 MeV solar energetic particle protons, as a function of radial distance. The parallel (solid line) and perpendicular (dashed line) mean-free-paths are shown, as well as the magnetic field focusing length (L, dotted line), and the ratio of the perpendicular to parallel mean-free-path (dash-dotted line).

(orange) Mars in a coordinate system co-rotating with the Sun-Earth line. As Figure 1 shows, the outward Hohmann trajectory follows closely the outward extension of the magnetic field line that connects the Earth with the Sun, a phenomenon that is referred to as the Hohmann-Parker effect (Posner et al., 2013). The term magnetic connection distance refers to the distance in longitude between the magnetic foot points at the Sun of two locations in the heliosphere, such as a SWx warning system and the Mars transfer vehicle. Note that during the return journey the Hohmann-Parker effect of small magnetic connection distances of the Mars transfer vehicle is also present but applies to explorers following the field line connecting Mars with the Sun, best shown in a coordinate system rotating with the Mars-Sun line.

With an appropriately equipped s/c at the Sun-Earth L4 location, short-term SEP forecasting schemes would be in a position to incorporate solar remote sensing information (characterized by EUV/X-ray intensities and magnetograms) from behind the W limb, effectively covering all relevant SEPs that affect the Earth/ Moon system. SEP transport is known to be most effective along magnetic field lines in the heliosphere (Richardson et al., 2014). Traveling outward to Mars under the influence of the Hohmann-Parker effect, the explorers' field line would be anchored near the region where Earth's magnetic field line is in the Sun, that is, near the W limb. Therefore, information from L4 would also help protect much of the outbound trajectory from Earth to Mars.

Timely short-term forecasts based on the REleASE system (Posner, 2007) from Earth-Sun L1 and Mars-Sun L1 can save astronauts from acute radiation sickness and would limit their lifetime exposure (Posner & Strauss, 2020). Depending on available shielding and radiation shelter, up to 10 cGy blood-forming organ dose can be saved in a worst-case scenario.

UMASEP and ESPERTA both suffer from a lack of observations from behind the W limb though, and would directly benefit from L4 observations, filling a critical gap, flares from behind the W limb, in their observational input streams. It appears likely that combining aspects of REleASE, UMASEP and ESPERTA, and taking into account all their required model inputs (relativistic electrons and protons, flare brightness and location, and low-frequency type-III radio burst occurrence) would make short-term SEP forecasting very POSNER ET AL.

10.1029/2021SW002777 8 of 27 robust and reliable. UMASEP and ESPERTA with full coverage of the SRH have not yet been considered for providing forecasts for the outbound journey to Mars.

The inward (or return) journey poses a different problem for short-term radiation forecast systems. As discussed in detail in Posner et al. (2013), the return journey's Hohmann-Parker effect influence is expressed predominantly in the exploration vehicle's proximity to the magnetic field line that connects Mars with the Sun. It has therefore been suggested to place a s/c with the needed input stream for the REleASE forecast, a relativistic electron instrument, at Mars-Sun L1. It has been shown that even a warning system placed farther away from the Sun than the explorers, there will be significant net advance warning time available.

However, while the maximum magnetic connection distance of the explorers from Earth as prescribed by the Hohmann-Parker effect (for average solar wind speed of ∼400 km/s) is 9° for the outward journey, it is larger from Mars, about 15°, during the return journey (see Table 1 in Posner and Strauss [2020]). It is expected that the accuracy of the REleASE forecast decreases with increasing magnetic connection distance of the location the forecast is intended for.

The Earth-Sun L4 location would potentially offer another vantage point for the source of a REleASE forecast. We analyzed this scenario and found, as shown in Figure 6, that the maximum connection distance would decrease for a significant amount of time during the return journey, The reason for this decrease in magnetic connection distance is the favorable passage of the Earth-Sun L4 s/c in the early/mid-phase of the return journey. Depending on solar wind speed conditions, assuming 300-500 km/s, on days 75-100 after injection of the transfer vehicle into the transfer orbit to Earth, the exploration vehicle can be directly aligned along the Parker spiral with Earth-Sun L4. During the more extended period of days ∼60-∼130, depending on the solar wind speed conditions, the REleASE forecast can potentially be more accurate than the forecast from Mars-Sun L1 alone. We calculate that the average connection distance under 300 km/s solar POSNER ET AL.

10.1029/2021SW002777 9 of 27 wind speed conditions would be 8.7° (400 km/s: 6.8°; 500 km/s: 5.6°) without the addition of Earth-Sun L4, and would decrease to 7.6° (400 km/s: 6.2°; 500 km/s: 5.3°) with the Earth-Sun L4 warning system included.

Another aspect of SEP radiation hazards is that of energetic storm particles (ESPs) directly associated with the passage of a CME-driven shock over the spacecraft. In rare circumstances, such as during the August 1972 event, ESPs can become a serious radiation hazard. While coronagraphic remote sensing can give indications for such events that are likely associated with extremely fast CMEs, there can be considerable uncertainty in the resulting energy spectrum and intensity at 1 AU and beyond unless directly observed by in-situ particle detectors. As seen in Figure 6, during days 80-120, the L4 location moves away from the Mars-Sun line. However, during the early phase, L4 is nearly radially aligned with the Exploration Vehicle. Such a scenario could provide several hours to days advance warning of hazardous conditions stemming from ESPs that often peak near the outward-moving CME shock. During the entire phase of the return journey, the combination of Earth-Sun L1 and Earth-Sun L4 bound the Mars-Sun line from both sides, adding key observations that would very likely detect hazardous conditions heading toward the Exploration Vehicle. We argue that the occurrence of hazardous ESPs, while rare, would not be missed during the return journey from Mars to Earth. Several studies have discussed SWx opportunities provided by Earth-Sun-L5-point observations , Gopalswamy, Davila, StCyr, et al., 2011Pevtsov et al., 2020). We add to these arguments the added protection from extreme energetic storm particle events during the late phase of the journey from Earth to Mars, as much of that journey occurs east of the Earth-Sun line, in or near the direction toward L5.

It is noteworthy that during the return journey, Earth-Sun L4 remote sensing would cover a continuously growing fraction of the SRH relevant for the Exploration Vehicle. It is centered approximately 70°W of the POSNER ET AL.

While likely less relevant immediately after injection from Mars-given the EV's large distance from the Sun at the time-SRH coverage from L4 becomes more and more relevant during the return journey, as SEPs can become more intense with decreasing radial distance from the Sun.

We conclude that both the remote-sensing and the in-situ aspects of an Earth-Sun L4 mission add significantly to radiation hazard safety for human exploration of the Moon and Mars, including the outward and inward journey.


The Non-Hohmann Scenario

The radiation exposure to Galactic Cosmic Ray ions on a journey to and from Mars, which are difficult to shield against due to their hard spectra, may only be reduced through reduction in total travel time. While the usage of the Hohmann trajectory is optimized for total payload delivery and will most likely be used for cargo ships, a compromise solution between payload and radiation exposure may lead to flight trajectory solutions for human explorers that are shorter, more direct. Such faster transfers can reduce the radiation exposure from galactic cosmic rays at a rate of ∼500 μGy/day .

For the sake of simplicity, express outward journeys are modeled here by travel along a Hohmann trajectories from Earth to destinations beyond Mars orbit, which result in a delayed launch window as compared to the nominal Hohmann launch window to Mars. Such trajectories also have on average higher radial velocities. (There may be other, similar solutions that assume both a smaller perihelion and a larger aphelion distance in order to optimize energy usage, but such solutions would not have significant impact on this discussion. The differences from the scenarios discussed here would be a small velocity component in the radial direction immediately after injection from Earth.) The higher initial tangential acceleration after launch would result in an outward velocity vector with respect to Mars when the exploration vehicle arrives at Mars, requiring additional deceleration energy.

L5-L1-L4 in Tandem: Improving Accuracy and Reliability of Forecasting Geomagnetic Disturbance Arrival at Earth


Introduction/Current State of Inner Heliospheric Solar Wind Modeling

There are several models capable of predicting the background or ambient solar wind. They vary from relatively simple, quick running models such as the Wang-Sheeley-Arge (WSA) model (Arge et al., 2004;McGregor et al., 2008;Wallace et al., 2019) to highly advanced MHD models such as Enlil (Odstrҫil et al., 2004(Odstrҫil et al., , 2005, CORHEL (Riley et al., 2012), MS-FLUKSS (T. K. Kim et al., 2014), Gamera (Zhang et al., 2019), SWMF (Tóth et al., 2012), and EUHFORIA (Pomoell & Poedts, 2018). WSA + Enlil (Odstrҫil et al., 2020) is a hybrid model that runs relatively quickly and has been used to make operational forecasts at NOAA since 2011 (Pizzo et al., 2011). Reliable forecasts of the ambient solar wind are critical for accurately predicting the arrival time of CMEs (Kilpua et al., 2019;Pizzo et al., 2015) or the magnetic connectivity of a spacecraft back to the Sun. There have been numerous validation studies evaluating the reliability and forecast capability of these models (e.g., MacNeice, 2009aMacNeice, , 2009bMacNeice et al., 2011;Norquist, 2013;Norquist & Meeks, 2010;Owens et al., 2005Owens et al., , 2008.

Virtually all coronal and solar wind models use global maps of the Sun's photospheric magnetic field as their primary driver. Historically, these maps have been constructed from magnetograms of the LOS magnetic field that have been converted to radial orientation, where it is assumed the field is radial (Svalgaard et al., 1978;Y.-M. Wang & Sheeley, 1992). More recently, global maps of the radial field are being constructed from vector magnetograms from SOLIS, SDO/HMI (Schou et al., 2012), and soon the PHI instrument on Solar Orbiter (SolO). However, as discussed below, there are a number of uncertainties and complexities intrinsic to these maps that often introduce errors into the coronal and solar wind solutions. Efforts to bypass some of these problems include using interplanetary scintillation (IPS) measurements of solar wind speed and density to drive solar wind models such as Enlil (Jackson et al., 2020) and MS-FLUKSS (Manoharan et al., 2015). All solar wind models require extrapolations of the photospheric magnetic field to provide the magnetic field used to drive them. While there have recently been successful attempts to measure the coronal magnetic field directly (see, e.g., Lagg et al., 2017), these measurements are generally low in the corona and in the plane of the sky and therefore not currently practical for direct use in solar wind modeling. However, such observations could be used to constrain and thus improve the reliability of magnetic field extrapolations.

Until the recent launch of SolO, constructing global maps of the photospheric magnetic field required acquiring about 27 days of magnetograms and then assembling them into maps, typically by using a weighting function that is sharply peaked at central meridian. Other approaches include constructing maps by taking narrow strips along the central meridians (as seen by the observer) from a series of magnetograms. The resulting maps represent the time history of central meridian-, that is, diachronic maps. But they do not represent what the Sun's field looks like at any given moment in time, that is, synchronic maps, which are the real need. Attempts to produce maps that are more nearly synchronic have been generated using flux transport models (e.g., Arge et al., 2011;Hickmann et al., 2015;Schrijver & DeRosa, 2003;Upton & Hathaway, 2014). While these models can generate maps that are more nearly synchronic in nature, they are still rife with problems. They have two critical limitations that have been discussed previously resulting from the lack of global, simultaneous observations: a) flux emergence on the solar far-side and b) large measurement uncertainties near the solar limb. These two issues create several problems in the maps used to drive models as summarized in Table 2  (e.g., Arge et al., 2013;Cash et al., 2015). Their subsequent, artificially sudden appearance on the east limb and their inclusion (often only partially) in the photospheric maps produce abrupt non-physical changes in the coronal and solar wind model solutions. This is especially troublesome for time-dependent modeling, as they produce non-physical effects that propagate throughout the model solution. Additionally, the lack of simultaneous observations, unreliable or lacking measurements of the polar fields, or the inclusion of only part of an active region produce artificial monopoles. These monopoles must be removed from the magnetic field maps before they can be used in coronal models to ensure the global magnetic field is divergence free. In general, there is no real way to do this properly, and correcting the input maps results in non-physical changes in the global solution. Both issues described above (and listed in Table 2) would be addressed by the addition of solar magnetic field measurements from L4 and L5. Another aspect we intend to address with missions inclined to the ecliptic plane as described in Section 5 is unreliable measurements of the Sun's polar field. These cause a major issue for coronal and solar wind models, as they are extremely sensitive to the field strengths there. This makes sense, because the large-scale coronal and heliospheric magnetic fields are normally controlled by the Sun's magnetic dipole moment, which is usually dominated by the polar fields. In fact, this problem makes solar wind predictions very unreliable whenever the heliospheric current sheet is flat and lies near the ecliptic plane (e.g., near solar minimum). The large uncertainties in the polar fields can easily shift model predictions of the current sheet up or down causing them to incorrectly predict polarities and solar wind source regions. Figure 9 shows a recent example of this problem (as viewed from Earth) during the time of the PSP fourth perihelion when both Earth and PSP were nearly co-aligned with respect to the Sun.


Polarimetry From L4 and L5

There are many advantages of adding observations of the photospheric magnetic field from the Lagrange point L4, especially when combined with simultaneous observations from vantage points at or near Earth and L5. The most obvious advantage is the increased instantaneous field of view, when combining the data from multiple observatories (e.g., Earth + L4 + L5). While combining magnetogram data from different instruments is generally non-trivial due differences in the instrumentation (e.g., wavelengths used, resolutions, etc.) and the complexities of intercalibration, simultaneous overlapping observations should help to accomplish this. Since the Sun rotates about ∼13.2° per day, this means no data in the map will be older than about 8 days, with the oldest data residing at the eastern edge of the Sun as viewed from an L5 observatory. This compares to current photospheric magnetic field maps, which lack upwards of 220° longitude (∼61% of the total map!) in new and simultaneous observations. Measurements in these maps can be POSNER ET AL.  as old as ∼17 days. If only Earth and L4 or L5 are available, then the longitudinal span in the maps missing simultaneous observation expands to ∼160° or roughly 12 days. Flux transport models can be used to help keep the portions of the maps lacking in new observations current by evolving the magnetic field forward in time, but presently they cannot address flux emergence. With simultaneous magnetograms from Earth + L4 + L5, only about a quarter of the Sun's surface magnetic field will lack new observations at any given moment in time, which will greatly reduce the likelihood of missing significant flux emergence and its subsequent adverse impact on SWx model forecasts. Flux transport models will also be able to manage these narrower gap regions much more effectively.

Helioseismic holography (Gizon et al., 2018;Liewer et al., 2014;Lindsey & Braun, 2000;Yang, 2018) and time-distance helioseismology (Duvall et al., 1993;Zhao et al., 2019) could be a further interesting application of magnetograph data from the Lagrange points L5 and particularly L4. Both techniques enable the detection and specification of active regions on the far side of the Sun. They can thus be monitored and even inserted into photospheric maps before they enter the field-of-view as seen from L5, which would further improve SWx predictions. In fact, Arge et al. (2013) demonstrated that this approach can improve solar wind forecasts.

Observatories at L4 and L5 in addition to an Earth-based one would enhance the quality, not only the quantity of observations of the photosphere seen over most of the solar disk as viewed from Earth. By combining the LOS components recorded from different vantage points, the magnetic field vector can be determined with higher precision, as the LOS component is usually measured with much greater reliability. Since all three spacecraft will be roughly in the ecliptic, mainly two components of the field can be determined in this manner. Similarly, such "stereoscopic observations" will also allow determining two components of the velocity vector instead of just the LOS component.

Another significant improvement would be the removal of the 180° ambiguity in the direction of the transverse component of the magnetic field vector innate to the Zeeman effect. This ambiguity is a bane for the accurate extrapolation of the magnetic field from the photosphere to the corona. Whereas potential fields only require measurements of the longitudinal component of the magnetic field, the more realistic non-linear force-free fields require the full magnetic vector (e.g., Wiegelmann et al., 2014). The methods currently available for removing the ambiguity all suffer from having to make assumptions about the magnetic field (Leka et al., 2009;Metcalf et al., 2006). By combining observations from L4 and Earth, overcoming this ambiguity will be possible without additional assumptions for a swathe of the solar surface covering roughly 60° in longitude (between the Sun-L4 and the Sun-Earth lines). If an identical magnetograph is also present at L5, then the ambiguity can be overcome over most of the visible disk of the Sun, allowing for greatly improved magnetic field extrapolations into the corona. The method is illustrated in Figure 10. The SolO/ PHI instrument, that is, the Polarimetric and Helioseismic Imager (Solanki et al., 2020) on board the Solar Orbiter mission (Müller et al., 2020), will provide the first observational data with which to test and validate these techniques (Rouillard et al., 2020).

Another advantage of having a spacecraft at L4 (best in conjunction with observations along the Sun-Earth line and at L5) is that it extends the time that a given solar pole is visible. As described in Section 3.1, coronal and solar wind models are highly sensitive to the strengths of the polar fields, which are poorly observed due to the Sun's small 7.23° axial tilt. While a given solar pole is technically visible for 6 months per year, it is only well observed (i.e., pole inclined toward Earth by more than 3.5°) for only about 4 months per year. This is illustrated in Figure 11. If an L4 mission orbiting in the ecliptic is included, then this length of time increases to 6 months. Adding an L5 mission to the mix increases it to 8 months for each pole. This also leads to the interesting situation where twice a year both poles are visible for 2 months at the same time at an angle greater than 3.5°. Putting aside the challenges of the required orbital dynamics, suppose two spacecraft are launched from Earth and sent to L4 and L5 such that they lie in a plane offset from the ecliptic by 14.5° (see the sketch at the top of Figure 13). This plane is tilted 7.23° from the heliographic equator. In this configuration, both solar poles can be kept in view by one of the spacecraft at an angle above 3.6° essentially for all times. In addition, the polar field measurements obtained from the magnetographs located at L4 and L5 would basically fill more of the gaps in the observations seen in Figure 11 and help to further constrain the ADAPT model flux transport parameters.

If the spacecraft could be launched to even higher inclinations to the ecliptic, it would almost certainly reduce the sizes of the error bars display in Figure 11. It is likely that an increase of a few degrees would result in important reductions in the observational uncertainties and thus further improve the flux transport model polar field predictions and enhance the accuracy of solar wind forecasts even more. The Solar Orbiter mission will spearhead high-latitude solar remote sensing observations. While two solar polar orbiters would be needed to permanently cover both solar poles simultaneously to drive solar wind models, overlap of a POSNER ET AL. possible combination of L4-L1-L5 with the Solar Orbiter mission could directly quantify the level of accuracy provided by the lower-latitude-only observations. This will give us insight in what latitude coverage will be needed in the long term to optimize solar wind forecasting models.

As discussed in Section 3.1, the lack of global, simultaneous observations of the Sun's photospheric magnetic field results in a number of issues and problems in current global magnetic field maps used to drive coronal and solar wind models, which can severely impact their forecast reliability. Minimizing the portions of these maps having very old observations will significantly improve the temporal consistency of the photospheric boundary conditions used to model the corona and thus answers the need of SWx for timely observational data (see e.g., Pevtsov et al., 2020;Vourlidas, 2015).

From a basic scientific standpoint, without reliable global and simultaneous observations of the Sun's magnetic field, it is difficult to determine whether a model solution disagrees with observations because of inadequate physics or due to problems with the input maps themselves. In general, no matter how good the physics is in a model, if the boundary conditions used to drive it are wrong, its solutions will be, to greater or lesser degree, wrong too. This problem is slowing progress in our understanding of the physics of the corona and solar wind, as well as the ability to model them for practical purposes (e.g., SWx forecasting).


Solar Wind Low-Latitude Structure and Temporal Evolution

As discussed in Section 3.1, the solar magnetic poles tend to have significant influence over the in-ecliptic portion of the solar wind. In particular, under near solar minimum conditions, both solar poles alternately control parts of the heliographic equator by filling it with plasma of its magnetic polarity. Extensions of polar coronal holes into lower latitudes can create fast solar wind streams that form corotating interaction regions at Earth. As shown in the PSP example, the latitudinal extents of fast streams, and the exact location of the heliographic current sheet are variable, and lack of solar polar magnetic field measurements make predictions uncertain.

The driving of these models and their in-situ validation has relied mostly on observations taken from Earth's direction. While driving with magnetograph data is still limited in this way, the in-ecliptic STEREO mission allowed increasing latitude coverage for validation of solar wind models with in-situ observations while drifting away from Earth. When the STEREOs passed the L4 and L5 points, the latitude coverage over the course of the year matched that shown in Figure 12. Here, in the first half of the year all three observing locations predominantly covered the southern heliographic latitude range, while moving as an ensemble to the northern hemisphere over the latter half of the year. The maximum latitude span of in-situ observations covered here is ∼10° (January and May, 3°N to 7°S, and July and November, 3°S to 7°N), followed by converging to ∼4° latitude coverage in early March and September. This ensemble-type movement in latitudes would be the result of both L4 and L5 launched into the ecliptic plane, or only one of them launched into the suggested orbit with 14.5° tilt toward the ecliptic (in that case, the times of maximum latitude coverage would be shifted, but then ensemble motion would be similar).

The maximum extent of in-situ latitude coverage would be reached by launching L4 and L5 into the suggested orbits, matching the latitudes shown in Figure 13. For the STEREO/Earth L1 combination, latitude coverage culminated in the late 2012 time frame, when the STEREOs were separated by ∼120° in longitude from each other and Earth. Advancing Understanding of Interplanetary and Interstellar Dust Populations From L4 and L5

The main component of interplanetary dust is zodiacal dust, a disk of debris which is ordered approximately by ecliptic latitude, unlike the solar wind and energetic particles in the heliosphere, which are generally ordered by heliographic or heliomagnetic latitude. Ulysses was the only spacecraft that carried a dust detector into high ecliptic latitudes, both north and south of the ecliptic plane, and thus for the first time measured a latitudinal profile of interplanetary dust (Wenzel et al., 1992). Yet, the three orbits of Ulysses and limited number of particles detected in the inner heliosphere, during its "fast latitude scans" were insufficient to fully characterize the orientation of the disk. Science questions related to the zodiacal dust cloud to be addressed by a mission to L4 or L5 that is inclined by 14.5° versus the ecliptic plane include: What is the vertical extent of the zodiacal dust cloud? What is its symmetry plane and what dynamics cause it to be inclined? What amount of β-meteoroids are escaping the system? Is there nanodust to be detected that is related to solar phenomena? Can interplanetary dust particles reside in the L4/L5 points and for how long?

The last question is long-standing: Ever since 1961, the existence of the Kordylewski clouds in the Moon-Earth system has been debated. These are (observed) clouds of interplanetary dust particles, residing in the Moon-Earth system's L5 point, which serves us here as an analogy to the Earth-Sun Lagrange points. Several observational and simulation studies have been undertaken of dust particles in the Moon-Earth system's L4 and L5 Lagrange points, concluding that it is in principle possible for these clouds to exist (e.g., Sliz-Balogh et al., 2018, but observational evidence (astronomical as well as in situ) remains weak. For the Venus-Sun system, simulations were performed where the stability of the Lagrange points for micron and sub-micron sized dust particles was examined, and these degraded quickly due to solar radiation pressure force and electromagnetic forces (Zhou et al., 2021). For the Earth-Sun system, mainly studies of the Trojans exist. One Trojan has been observationally confirmed to reside in Earth-Sun L4 Lagrange point (Connors et al., 2011). Note that the STEREO A and B s/c did not measure excess dust when they passed through the L4 and L5 regions, respectively, in late 2009 (Malaspina et al., 2015). This mission-if a dust detector is on board-may thus possibly give or exclude evidence of longer residence times of (large) dust in the Earth-Sun's Lagrange points. Impact speeds may be low though.

Another important aspect of dust science that is accessible from the inner heliosphere is ISD. Far outside of the ecliptic plane, the ISD flux (∼1.5 10 −4 m −2 sec −1 ) by far dominates the total flux while in the ecliptic plane, it makes up about up to 30% of the flux (Grün et al., 1997). Ulysses was thus an ideal platform for monitoring the ISD flow, and it did so for 16 years with a 0.1 m 2 detector. This time span is important, because the ISD flux depends on the solar cycle. Every other 11 years, the ISD particles, in particular those smaller than about half a micrometer in radius, focus and defocus toward and from the solar equatorial plane throughout the 22-year Hale cycle. Ulysses detected about 500-1,000 ISD particles with masses between 10 −12 and 10 −19 kg and provided the first ever direct detection of interstellar dust in the solar system (Grün et al., 1993(Grün et al., , 2019. More missions followed, even including composition analysis and sample return.

The suggested orbits of L4 and L5 have several advantages for the interstellar dust investigations: L4 will reach its highest latitude of 14.5° above the ecliptic plane in the early January time frame each year, while L5 will be at this point in early November. There, the IDP density is reduced to ∼30% of the density in the ecliptic plane. Both L4 and L5 will be at a longitude in the heliocentric ecliptic frame of ca. 240° and will thus be ideally moving into the ISD flow coming from approximately longitude 255° (Strub et al., 2015). This yields high dust impact velocities of nominally 40 km/s. Depending on particle size, velocities may vary between ca. 30 and 45 km/s. Moving "against" the stream of ISD also yields higher fluxes (Ulysses "only" had average impact velocities of about 26 km/s of the interstellar dust on the detector and thus lower fluxes), and higher impact speeds also augments composition analyses of ISD particles, since time-of-flight mass spectrometers are based on ionization of dust particles and target material upon impact, which depends on impact speed. The motion of the s/c against the stream of ISD at the orbit phase between ascending node and highest ecliptic latitude not only yields higher fluxes and higher impact velocities, but it is also here where the interplanetary and interstellar dust come from opposite directions, which simplifies distinguishing between the two populations.

If L4/L5 missions are launched around 2030 with a lifetime of 5 years, then they would be in place during solar minimum of the "focusing phase" of the solar magnetic cycle. The L1-L4-L5 missions would thus be ideally positioned in the focusing zone of ISD near the ecliptic plane. At this time, the portion of small ISD particles that can reach 1 AU is enhanced. An orbit with varying ecliptic latitudes provides a compelling opportunity to study the predicted ISD variability with the solar cycle (Sterken et al., 2012).


L4 Mission Architecture

There have been numerous design studies published about stationing a spacecraft at L5, but we are not aware of any examinations of L4 as a vantage point. Since many of the aspects of operating from an L4 vantage point are equivalent to L5, it is useful to review some of the published studies before presenting our findings.

A short description of an instrument and processor development needed for a possible L5 mission was provided by Akioka et al. (2005), but details of the mission design were not discussed.  described the mission design details for an L5 observatory carrying both remote sensing and in situ instrumentation. They reported that a hybrid propulsion architecture containing both solar electric and chemical propulsion was the most effective solution for the cruise and station-keeping phases of their proposed 900 kg spacecraft. Strugarek et al. (2015) proposed a pair of >500 kg spacecraft carrying remote sensing and in situ instrumentation. A single launch would put both in heliocentric drift orbits, but they did not specify what propulsion system would provide the necessary delta-V such that one leads Earth by 34° and the other lags Earth by the same amount. Lavraud et al. (2016) described a single micro satellite based on the PROBA platform with a separate propulsion module, with the estimated mass for the entire space vehicle more than 550 kg. They proposed a slow drift orbit toward L5 for 3 years, followed by a >1 year delta-V stopping maneuver using low thrust electrical propulsion before entering a stabilized 0.1 AU halo orbit around L5. Vourlidas (2015) reviewed several proposed implementation concepts and argued that an L5 mission should take priority over L4; however, he also noted that L4 is a natural follow-on because of the invisibility of energetic particle sources that affect Earth without warning.

The STEREO mission  provides a useful baseline in terms of payload composition [multiple remote sensing and in situ instrumentation]; a 1 A.U. environment; and communication of continuous low latency beacon data as well as daily downloads of full-resolution telemetry from comparable distances (Driesman et al., 2008). Of course, the STEREO spacecraft were in a heliocentric drift orbit, as they did not have onboard propulsion to stop and remain at L4/L5. But the actual communications rates for the full-resolution telemetry stream as the STEREO spacecraft drifted through L4/L5 were 240-360 kbps using the DSN 34 m antennas. Comparable data downlink capability is also found on PSP with conservatively estimated 138 kbs at a spacecraft-Earth distance of 1 AU, using a 0.6 m high-gain antenna with a 40 W RF system in Ka-band (Kinnison et al., 2013). The combined launch mass of the twin STEREO spacecraft was ∼1,300 kg, which included a 62 kg of hydrazine mono-propellant system that was capable of providing ∼180 m/s delta-V on each spacecraft.


Mission Design and Resource Assessment

We have examined conceptual mission design criteria for transfer to L4 with the following goals: Minimize cruise time to L4; increase the ecliptic inclination to optimize simultaneous view of both Sun's poles in conjunction with any Earth-bound mission and a simultaneous, similarly inclined L5 mission; and a stable orbit in the L4 region for multiple years. We examined three possibilities for propulsion requirements to increase the orbital inclination and drift-then-dwell at L4: launch vehicle performance; onboard chemical propulsion only; and onboard solar electric propulsion (SEPr). But like the mission concept described by  we found that the volumetric requirements for relying solely on onboard chemical propulsion were prohibitive, so we examined combinations of these techniques as an alternate possibility.

The launch energy (known as C3 and defined as the square of the hyperbolic excess velocity of the spacecraft with respect to Earth) is a measure of the velocity that must be supplied to the spacecraft by a launch vehicle. For example, assuming C3 values < 0 km 2 /s 2 , after a cruise phase of ∼4 years an additional 650 m/s delta-V would be necessary for an in-ecliptic orbital insertion at L4. To increase the orbital inclination to ∼14° at that time would cost an additional 7.5 km/s delta-V.

An alternative approach would be to have the launch vehicle supply sufficient C3 to change the orbital inclination initially. Our study found that with a C3 ∼25 km 2 /s 2 then an orbital inclination of ∼10° could be achieved, requiring onboard SEPr to provide an additional 2.5 km/s delta-V for about 90 days at L4 to achieve the desired 14.5° inclination. There are several existing launch services that can meet this C3 requirements today assuming a ∼2,000 kg spacecraft.

We also examined the possibility of launching two nearly identical spacecraft on a single vehicle, with one targeted to L4 and the other to L5 as shown in Figures 15 and 16. Each spacecraft would achieve the desired 14.5° inclination at their respective libration point. The orbits would be phased by choosing launch windows centered around the periods when Earth crossed the heliographic equator to maximize viewing the Sun's poles from Earth, L4, and L5 (see Figure 13) so that the improved background solar wind modeling discussed in Section 3.3 could be accomplished. An initial study indicates that, without altering the delta-V requirement for the L4 vehicle, only a small amount of additional mass would be needed as propulsion for the vehicle destined for L5. It appears there are numerous solutions in the trade space between launch vehicle-supplied C3 and onboard propulsion for delta-V on the L4 and L5 vehicles. It is likely there will be numerous cost-effective options for launch vehicles in the foreseeable future that will meet the C3 requirements for this conceptual mission.


L4/L5 Payload Options

While a detailed assessment of the mission payload is beyond the scope of this work, we list in Table 3 estimated resource requirements of instrumentation that would support the various science and SWx aspects we discussed in previous sections.

In this context, instrumentation missing from the STEREO payload are a photospheric vector magnetograph, whose measurements are to characterize the Sun's magnetic field and to drive many relevant physics-based models of eruptive events. A candidate instrument has been described recently by Staub et al. (2020) for a potential L5 mission led by ESA Space Situational Awareness Programme (Kraft et al., 2016) Pers. comm. R. Srama/Univ. Moreover, a dedicated dust detector would support the objectives we laid out in Section 4. This detector would require placement on the ram side of the s/c. While L4 would have significant accommodation space for a dust detector there, this would likely not be the case for L5, where the ram side would be used by the communications system and the heliospheric imaging system.

The tabulation of resource requirements shows that power, mass and telemetry requirements for the L4 mission are within the capabilities of current deep-space missions with Ka-band communications. The STEREO example shows that the full telemetry listed in Table 3 can be communicated to the ground with 1/3 coverage (8 h/day). While latency requirements may impose continuous beacon downlink for a subset of data, the bulk of the data is produced by vector magnetograph, EUV imager and coronagraphic and heliospheric imaging, part of which could be communicated to the ground with several hours latency.


Summary and Conclusions

This work highlights several benefits for scientific understanding and for human space exploration stemming from a mission to the L4 Lagrangian point. The SRH, which coincides with the hemisphere in view from L4, is the source of all potentially hazardous solar energetic particle events at Earth. In combination with existing assets at Earth, continuous, detailed surveillance of active regions of 2/3 of a solar rotation would be established. An L4 mission would fill observational gaps near and beyond the W limb of the Sun that hamper current short-term radiation forecasting schemes for the Earth-Moon system, and similarly would provide inputs that would advance probabilistic long-term SEP forecasting tools that may in the future provide both SEP-and all-clear forecasts, both critical for operations to and at the Moon.

We expanded the analysis also to Mars explorers, which, on their journeys to and from Mars, would be particularly vulnerable to SEPs. On fast journeys to Mars, which would reduce exposure to cosmic rays considerably, explorers would be magnetically connected to regions behind the solar W limb as viewed from Earth, but well within view from L4. This along with the expanded longitude coverage that L4 provides for solar observations during astronauts' stay at Mars, would make an L4 mission a vital part of human Mars exploration plans.

We also analyzed potential contributions of an L4 observatory in the context of L1 and L5 observations on modeling and scientific understanding of the inner-heliosphere solar wind structure. This understanding is vital for our ability to predict the most severe geomagnetic storms at Earth, which are driven by Earth-directed CMEs. At current, coronal and solar wind models use global maps of the Sun's photospheric magnetic field. These maps are diachronic, that is, not all regions of the Sun are observed simultaneously but recorded over time, currently based only on Earth-bound observations. L4 and L5 missions would reduce the wait time for a complete map to ∼12 days. This alone would drastically improve inner heliosphere solar wind modeling. Flux emergence could be constrained further, even on the Sun's far side, through helioseismic holography, which would benefit from L4 observations. Moreover, L4 offers another platform for viewing the entire Sun-Earth line with coronographic and heliospheric imaging technology, but well out of the way of the associated SEPs that are associated with the Earth-directed CME (Posner et al., 2014).

We discussed the advantage an L4 mission would provide if combined with an Earth-bound mission for the reduction of ambiguity in the observation of solar magnetic fields through Zeeman polarimetry. Two magnetographs when placed 60° apart would resolve the inherent ambiguity in azimuthal magnetic field components, as illustrated in Figure 10, applying to quiet background fields, but also to active regions that rotate into the SRH. The added knowledge of vector magnetic fields combined with growing machine learning and AI technology could lead to breakthroughs in solar activity forecasting and understanding.

Besides lack of longitudinal coverage, current solar wind models driven by magnetograms also suffer from lack of polar magnetic field constraints. We showed an example of solar wind model predictions for the PSP under solar minimum conditions. These predictions are extremely sensitive to polar fields, a problem that can only be improved with better observations, hence we suggest a specific change the orbital plane for L4 and L5. The ecliptic view angle of the solar poles varies between ±7.23° of heliographic latitude over the course of the year, with generally only one pole visible at a time. If L4 and L5 are added, the lack of visibility of both poles would be reduced to 1/3 (as shown in Figure 12). A significant step forward, though, would be an inclined injection of missions to L4 and L5, so that their orbits are located on the opposite side of the heliographic equator. If injected at the same absolute inclination as Earth, both solar poles would always be visible from at least one s/c. Moreover, in-situ observations of solar wind and magnetic field from L4-L5-L1 would systematically scan the region around the heliospheric current sheet and help determine its location and movement, adding the means to independently test the accuracy of inner-heliosphere solar wind models.

Polar viewing angles as suggested are, admittedly, still shallow (∼3.6-7.2°), but we find that they would have direct impact on existing models, such as ADAPT. The Solar Orbiter mission, if operated simultaneously with our suggested L4-L1-L5 architecture, could provide a means for testing the required inclination of L4 and L5 missions so that a future operational space weather architecture would be optimized for driving inner heliosphere models.

New generations of cosmic dust instruments in combination with the suggested orbits for L4 and L5 can also provide the next big step in interplanetary and interstellar dust research close to our home planet.
